Data has already been integrated under: Lyons, B. (2022). Partisanship, not illiteracy: Explaining older Americans’ vulnerability to dubious news.;
We know this form e-mail exchange with the author: "I should also mention though that this is 
mostly a re-analysis of the dataset- the Nov/Dec survey you might have 
already included for example (used in "A digital media literacy intervention increases discernment between mainstream and false news in the United States and India") The Oct/Nov and Nov/Dec survey data was also used in "Overconfidence in news judgments is associated with false news susceptibility." I used all three surveys in "Why we should rethink the third-person effect: disentangling bias and earned confidence using behavioral data."

reference: Moravec, P. L., Kim, A., Dennis, A. R., & Minas, R. K. (2022). Do You Really Know if It’s True? How Asking Users to Rate Stories Affects Belief in Fake News on Social Media. Information Systems Research, 33(3), 887–907. https://doi.org/10.1287/isre.2021.1090

reference: Gao, M., Xiao, Z., Karahalios, K., & Fu, W.-T. (2018). To Label or Not to Label: The Effect of Stance and Credibility Labels on Readers’ Selection and Perception of News Articles. Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction, 2(CSCW), 1–16. https://doi.org/10.1145/3274324
Additional remarks: does not measure accuracy

reference: Wagner, M. C., & Boczkowski, P. J. (2019). The reception of fake news: The interpretations and practices that shape the consumption of perceived misinformation. Digital Journalism, 7(7), 870–885.
Additional remarks: interview study, does not measure accuracy, focuses on fake news

reference: Salvi, C., Iannello, P., Cancer, A., McClay, M., Rago, S., Dunsmoor, J. E., & Antonietti, A. (2021). Going Viral: How Fear, Socio-Cognitive Polarization and Problem-Solving Influence Fake News Detection and Proliferation During COVID-19 Pandemic. Frontiers in Communication, 5, 562588. https://doi.org/10.3389/fcomm.2020.562588
Additional remarks: did not use real world news items and do not provide summary stats

reference: Faragó, L., Kende, A., & Krekó, P. (2020). We Only Believe in News That We Doctored Ourselves: The Connection Between Partisanship and Political Fake News. Social Psychology, 51(2), 77–90. https://doi.org/10.1027/1864-9335/a000391
Additional remarks: created their own news (even though apparently based on social media discourse) and focused on fake news. Study 1 appears to have also featured true news, but no description in the paper about them.

reference: Moravec, P., Kim, A., & Dennis, A. (n.d.). Flagging Fake News: System 1 vs. System 2.
Additional remarks: used made up headlines and focused on fake news

reference: Leeder, C. (2019). How college students evaluate and share “fake news” stories. Library & Information Science Research, 41(3), 100967. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.lisr.2019.100967
Additional remarks: does not provide relevant summary statistics -no SDs provided.

reference: Saadany, H., Mohamed, E., & Orasan, C. (2020). Fake or real? A study of Arabic satirical fake news. ArXiv Preprint ArXiv:2011.00452.
Additional remarks: no participants who evaluate accuarcy, aim is to train an alogrythm to detect fake news

reference: Fazio, L. (2020). Pausing to consider why a headline is true or false can help reduce the sharing of false news. Harvard Kennedy School Misinformation Review. https://doi.org/10.37016/mr-2020-009
Additional remarks: do not measure perceived accuracy, focus on sharing

reference: Freeze, M., Baumgartner, M., Bruno, P., Gunderson, J. R., Olin, J., Ross, M. Q., & Szafran, J. (2021). Fake Claims of Fake News: Political Misinformation, Warnings, and the Tainted Truth Effect. Political Behavior, 43(4), 1433–1465. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11109-020-09597-3
Additional remarks: not only did they make their news up, but also did they pair true news warning labels for fake news (misleading lables); no clear control condition

reference: Santos, R., Pedro, G., Leal, S., Vale, O., Pardo, T., Bontcheva, K., & Scarton, C. (2020). Measuring the impact of readability features in fake news detection. Proceedings of the 12th Language Resources and Evaluation Conference, 1404–1413.
Additional remarks: no participants who evaluate accuarcy, aim is to train an alogrythm to detect fake news

reference: Ahinkorah, B. O., Ameyaw, E. K., Hagan, J. E., Seidu, A.-A., & Schack, T. (2020). Rising Above Misinformation or Fake News in Africa: Another Strategy to Control COVID-19 Spread. Frontiers in Communication, 5, 45. https://doi.org/10.3389/fcomm.2020.00045
Additional remarks: does not provide any data

reference: Gaozhao, D. (2021). Flagging fake news on social media: An experimental study of media consumers’ identification of fake news. Government Information Quarterly, 38(3), 101591. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.giq.2021.101591
Additional remarks: does not provide relevant summary statistics and public data is not available to calculate them ourselves

reference: Wasserman, H., & Madrid-Morales, D. (2019). An Exploratory Study of “Fake News” and Media Trust in Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa. African Journalism Studies, 40(1), 107–123. https://doi.org/10.1080/23743670.2019.1627230
Additional remarks: did not let participants rate news headlines

reference: Simko, J., Hanakova, M., Racsko, P., Tomlein, M., Moro, R., & Bielikova, M. (2019). Fake News Reading on Social Media: An Eye-tracking Study. Proceedings of the 30th ACM Conference on Hypertext and Social Media, 221–230. https://doi.org/10.1145/3342220.3343642
Additional remarks: some of the fake news articles were made up by the authors

reference: Corbu, N., Bârgăoanu, A., Buturoiu, R., & Ștefăniță, O. (2020). Does fake news lead to more engaging effects on social media? Evidence from Romania. Communications, 45(s1), 694–717. https://doi.org/10.1515/commun-2019-0152
Additional remarks: study relied on a single news items that researchers created various versions of (among which some that were factually not accurate)

reference: Garg, N., & Yadav, M. (n.d.). Fact-Checking and Beliefs: Field Experiment in India [Data set]. American Economic Association. https://doi.org/10.1257/rct.7923
Additional remarks: does not report relevant summary stats; we contacted the authors three times because India and great study, but no response, so dissapointing.

reference: Baptista, J. P., Correia, E., Gradim, A., & Piñeiro-Naval, V. (2021). The Influence of Political Ideology on Fake News Belief: The Portuguese Case. Publications, 9(2), 23. https://doi.org/10.3390/publications9020023
Additional remarks: they use a very asymmetric scale, and results favor our hypotheses, including it seems like cheating

reference: Calvillo, D. P., & Smelter, T. J. (2020). An initial accuracy focus reduces the effect of prior exposure on perceived accuracy of news headlines. Cognitive Research: Principles and Implications, 5(1), 55. https://doi.org/10.1186/s41235-020-00257-y
Additional remarks: no clear control condition (we collected data anyways but exclude it for our analysis)

reference: Emma Hoes et al. (2023) Prominent Misinformation Interventions Reduce Misperceptions but Increase Skepticism
Additional remarks: researchers made up their fake news items (we collected data anyways, since didn't realize this first, but will exclude this data from all analysis)
